footer.desc: DigiFinland ja Sitra ovat tuoneet Suomeen avoimeen lähdekoodiin perustuvan Polis-verkkoalustan. Poliksen tarkoituksena on mahdollistaa suurien ryhmien osallistuminen rakentavaan mielipiteiden vaihtoon, valitun aihepiirin ympärillä.

overview.title: Overview
overview.text: Polis is a real-time survey system that helps identify the different ways a large group of people think about a divisive or complicated topic. Here’s a basic breakdown of some terms you’ll need to know in order to understand this report.
overview.term_participants_text: These are the people who participated in the conversation by voting and writing statements. Based on how they voted, each participant is sorted into an opinion group.
overview.term_statements_text: Participants may submit statements for other participants to vote on. Statements are assigned a number in the order they’re submitted.
overview.term_opinion_groups_text: These are the people who participated in the conversation by voting and writing statements. Based on how they voted, each participant is sorted into an opinion group.
overview.ownername_text: This pol.is conversation was run by

beeswarm.title: How divisive was the conversation?
beeswarm.text: Statements (here as little circles) to the left were voted on the same way—either everyone agreed or everyone disagreed. Statements to the right were divisive—participants were split between agreement and disagreement.
beeswarm.howto: Hover to see the statement text. Start on the far right to find out what the most divisive statement was.

all_comments.title: All statements
all_comments.text: Group votes across all statements, excluding those statements which were moderated out.

majority.title: Majority
majority.text: Here's what most people agreed with.
majority.desc: 60% or more of all participants voted one way or the other, regardless of whether large amounts of certain minority opinion groups voted the other way.

participant_groups.title: Opinion Groups
participant_groups.text: Across {{param1}} total participants, {{param2}} opinion groups emerged. There are two factors that define an opinion group. First, each opinion group is made up of a number of participants who tended to vote similarly on multiple statements. Second, each group of participants who voted similarly will have also voted distinctly differently from other groups.
participant_groups.grp_desc: Statements which make this group unique, by their votes:

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.text: The demographic breakdown of each group, as self reported by agreeing and disagreeing on statements marked 'metadata' by moderators.

uncertainty.title: Areas of uncertainty
uncertainty.text: Across all {{param1}} participants, there was uncertainty about the following statements. Greater than 30% of participants who saw these statements 'passed'.
uncertainty.desc: Areas of uncertainty can provide avenues to educate and open dialogue with your community.

graph.title: Graph
graph.text: Which statements were voted on similarly? How do participants relate to each other?
graph.desc: In this graph, statements are positioned more closely to statements which were voted on similarly. Participants, in turn, are positioned more closely to statements on which they agreed, and further from statements on which they disagreed. This means participants who voted similarly are closer together.
graph.click_text: Click a statement, identified by its number, to explore regions of the graph.
